newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: LME copper tipped to fall after squeeze unravels.
newsitem.headline: LME copper tipped to fall after squeeze unravels.

text.p: London Metal Exchange (LME) copper prices are seen falling slowly later on Tuesday after a technical squeeze on nearby supplies fell apart, dealers said.

The cash/threes backwardation, which had hit US$210 recently, was seen in Asian trade at arond $85/95 against a close on Monday in London of $87/97. Another trader pegged the backwardation here at $90/100.
"It (copper) should come off. I think the squeeze is done," a dealer for a metal trading company said. "Prices are going to probably slide lower."
Three month copper was quoted by the trade at 0200 GMT at $2,365/70 a tonne against the late quote in London on Monday of $2,367/69.

But LME metal brokers Brandeis said falling LME copper stocks and supply problems in Chile, the world's largest producer, raises "the potential for the spreads to flare out again, particularly as the period of tightness is said to extend towards early May dates."
LME copper stocks reached 141,800 tonnes yesterday, down nearly 20,000 tonnes from the level three weeks ago of about 160,000 tonnes.

Traders said any drop in copper prices may be temporary because of possible supply problems due to labour unrest in the Escondida mine in northern Chile and a decision by workers at the Quebrada Blanca mine on the Chilean-Bolivian border to go on strike from April 30.
"The problems in Chile will underpin copper prices for the next two to three weeks," the general manager of a Japanese metal trading company said. "I think copper will get stronger."
Quebrada Blanca is owned by Canada's Cominco Ltd and Teck Resources International. Escondida is owned by Broken Hill Proprietary and RTZ-CRA.
The rest of the base metals business in Asia slowed down due to the Golden Week holiday season in Japan and the May 1 holiday observed in other countries around the region.
China has not been seen selling any copper in the market and will probably wait for the following week before making any moves, dealers said.
"The Chinese are absent from the market at the moment," one dealer said.
Singapore-based traders were also monitoring copper stocks in the LME warehouse in the city state.

Copper stocks here reached 19,825 tonnes on Monday, down from a peak in late February of 56,475 tonnes. Far East dealers said LME copper stocks should dip 2,000-4,000 tonnes when the stocks report is released at 0800 GMT.
